descriptionSet.description: An image showing an Indian woman lounging on a carpet resting her head on one hand and wearing a sari and traditional jewellery - bangles, arm-bands, anklets and hair accessories.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: 13519
text-en: No. 78 - Sleeping Hindoo woman.
text-en: Gobind Ram & Ooday Ram, Jaipur.

description-en: An image showing an Indian woman lounging on a carpet resting her head on one hand and wearing a sari and traditional jewellery - bangles, arm-bands, anklets and hair accessories. (gs/sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Usually the only women we see in colonial postcards are native, as we see in the sexually charged image of the "Sleeping Hindoo Woman". (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The native women in this postcard is subject to the same picturesque aesthetic the native landscapes that she inhabited were subjected to. However, one wonders, why when it was deemed appropriate to show a Begum in her boudoir, the white woman or "memsahib" rarely was. Where was the memsahib in the imagery? It is not that white women were completely absent from colonial postcards. The European women who were depicted in the postcards were usually missionaries or travelers, and within the colonial school room sub-genre, the only European in the image was often the white school mistress.Therefore, the spaces they occupied in these images were either defined by the "good works" they performed, or by their journeys to exotic locations. The private realm of the memsahib was in "purdah" so to speak. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The same image appears under the title "Jaipur woman" on "Images of Asia", http://www.imagesofasia.com/html/india/jaipur-woman.html (Rianne Siebenga) (ma)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
